results.title: Men like me
results.brief_description: “Men like me” is a collaboration between the filmmaker and Dale Michaels and was made in 1994 when female to male transgender was relatively unfamiliar to the broader community and rarely discussed. Informative and sensitively presented the film uses interviews, vox pops, archival footage and stills, combined with computer animated images and narration by Susan Long and Dale Michaels.

results.title: Kombi Karma
results.brief_description: Kombi Karma examines a cultural icon through the eyes of a diverse group of VW Kombi van lovers. Rachael travels the Victorian countryside in her Kombi and describes her camping trips as ‘more comfortable than being at home’. David, a Kombi enthusiast for over 30 years, is fascinated by the van’s early beginnings as an economical utilities vehicle in occupied Germany during World War II. Some tell of their love of the Kombi’s idiosyncratic design, ‘I love the box shape because it’s such a practical thing to put things in’. Andrew lovingly restores Kombis and believes ‘once you’re bitten by it, it never really goes away, once you own one you really wouldn’t want to own any other sort of car’. And Jan has learned to love Kombis again after her former partner smashed her newly restored Kombi to pieces with a wood splitter. But perhaps Ben sums it up best when he explains that being a Kombi devotee means that ‘you are someone who enjoys the journey as much as the destination’.

results.title: Global insights 4
results.brief_description:
Global Insights 4 is a compilation of short video works of a subversive political nature, sourced from videoactivists, cultural saboteurs and ‘serious’ documentary-makers from around the world.
Pieces featured include an alternative US response to the incidents of September 11 2001, made by Indymedia NYC soon after the event; scenes from the front line of the democracy struggle in Malaysia. A remarkable sequence of (unarmed) indigenous peasants in Mexico taking over an army base; a Korean perspective on the rise of the new global economic orthodoxy and the resistance to it; the ‘no borders’ movement in Europe and Australia against the deportation and detention of refugees.
Adverts peppered throughout the program are actually ‘subverts’ - biting satirical 30-second statements about consumerism, gender, sexuality and possibilities for reshaping the world. Producers of this form range from disaffected advertisers to teenagers with an ironic message about climate change.
The Global Insights videos have seen hundreds of free public screenings from Tamil Nadu to Antarctica - inspiring grass-roots people’s action and fostering an independent and accessible screen culture globally.
Global Insights is put together on a miniscule budget by volunteers. It is a collaboration between hundreds of independent media makers around the world.

results.title: Songlines in the city. Episode 1
results.creator_credit: Peter Lane, Glen Edwards, Grant Hansen, Campbell Manderson, Fiona Dean, Rob Nairn and SKA TV
results.brief_description:
The Shows Songlines in the City is hosted by two of Melbourne’s Indigenous Musicians, Kutcha Edwards and Grant Hansen, both former members of well known Indigenous rock act Blackfire, and radio stalwarts at local community radio station 3CR.
The three shows have a magazine format with interviews and performances with some of Australia’s leading Aboriginal and non-indigenous artists, including Richard Frankland, Lou Bennet, Andy Alberts, Deniece Hudson, Paul Hester and Nick Barker. All the artists appearing on the show are involved with the Songlines Aboriginal Music Corporation Mentorship Program.
Actors, filmmakers and community members are also profiled. Segments include ‘Kids Talk’ at a local Aboriginal child-care centre, and a chat with koori students involved in an innovative education program
Episode One includes performances by Deniece Hudson with Nick Barker, and Kutcha and Grant with Paul Hester. It also includes the Kids Talk segment, Kate Munroe with the koori news, and interviews.
Community Context
‘Songlines in the City, Episode One’ is one of three half hour shows shot as a pilot for an ongoing indigenous series on Community Television Station Channel 31, Melbourne.
In 2001, SKA TV (a Community Television Production Group) approached Kutcha and Grant with the idea of a local indigenous TV show. SKA applied for and received $2500 from the City of Darebin to assist in the production of the pilots.
Community TV Production Groups RMITV and SKA TV provided in-kind assistance with equipment, facilities and crews, and produced the shows together with Kutcha, Grant, and Fiona Dean.
As a result of this mentoring project, the Aboriginal community received training funding to continue Songlines in the City as an ongoing Victorian koori show in 2002 on Channel 31, Melbourne.

results.title: Pathways
results.material_description: video, projections, text, audio, bespoke screens, tiered  wooden seating , timber and LED strips
results.brief_description:
A collaboration between artist-filmmaker Jeff Doring and the Ngarinyin Aboriginal Corporation. This spatial installation provides access and insight into the art and culture of the Ngarinyin people. The intention is to record and interpret a broad spectrum of Ngarinyin knowledge and law. The work consists of five discrete and interrelated elements:
1. The Introduction zone: a space consisting of a text, audio, visual introduction to the installation.
2. The Water and Wanjina zone: a corridor with apertures that open on the side to reveal visual works.
3. The Man Blood Law zone: a three screen installation with tiered seating that lies at the end of the Water and Wanjina corridor.
4. The Cave zone: an exhibition space which spatially represents a cave with images projected inside it.
5. The Today zone: a space which provides a contemporary perspective on the exhibition via a web installation.

results.title: Eager to Write (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions, L Reichstein F'tion, W Buckland F'tion and Andrew Scollo
results.brief_description: For children, the process of learning to write is a gradual and experimental one. This program follows the progress of children of different ages in the classroom. Follows a Myer Foundation program at Moonee Ponds West Primary School with Lorraine Wilson.

results.title: Street kids
results.creator_credit: York St Film Productions, Film Victoria, Kent Chadwick, Leigh Tilson and Rob Scott
results.brief_description: A documentary about homeless youths, some as young as 10, surviving by any means on the streets of Melbourne. Various young people are interviewed about their situation and their search for jobs and accommodation. Highlights the frustrations they face and the resultant temptation to fall into crime and prostitution in order to survive. Police and social workers who deal with these young people from day to day comment on the situation and how they attempt to alleviate the despair of those they encounter. Use of voice-overs (street kids talking about their lives) is very effective as well as disturbing. A courageous and compelling documentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: York St Film Productions, Film Victoria, Kent Chadwick, Leigh Tilson and Rob Scott
